full_text: the problem we face in discussing coronavirus is our blindspot to outlier events, and by extension existential risk. a new, lethal, highly-communicable virus, if even contained, is *certainly* more dangerous than a widespread flu we already understand. and this isn't contained.framed another way, coronavirus is an asymmetric risk. we can reasonably estimate the number of people who will die this year from flu. but there's currently no predicting coronavirus. its impact could be negligible, or it could be the deadliest pandemic in history.the trouble of course is not losing our minds every time a new virus appears, because there will *always* be a new virus. but one of them, eventually, will bring us to our knees. we need to be vigilant.
labels: fear, panic, virus, pandemic, fear<|endoftext|> counter-intuitive, crazy, overreaction, science, virology<|endoftext|> epidemics, politics, politics, pandemic, panda<|endoftext|>

one thing i have been wondering in the shower, lately: did the world end in 1989? i mean that literally. first, do me a solid and imagine an advanced civilization capable of running perfect, or near-perfect historical simulations. THREAD. https://t.co/b6j11YzuAnthere are many reasons future humanity (FH) might want to run sims: pleasure, distraction, and experimentation all come to mind. but history — simulating our past to better understand ourselves — is my favorite. now: what happens when a simulation ends?a moral question first. is FH comfortable with 'turning off' the lives of billions of simulated beings that think they're real? that maybe are, in some sense, real? or in a world of presumably limitless energy does FH rather simply... let their simulations run?historical accuracy of any historical sim would of course be of paramount importance. as bugs emerge (inaccuracies or impossible physical phenomena) a team of folks — let's call them referees — would likely patch "the story." but when the story ends, the refs go home. then what?the cold war, our atomic awakening and the dawn of meaningful computing, would be a JUICY sim. but the cold war ended with the fall of the berlin wall. if that were us — if that is our sim — we were "freed" in 1989. the refs went home thirty years ago.in a rogue sim, small, unchecked errors in historical accuracy give way to larger errors. things become increasingly unreal. fashion, culture, politics don't make sense because they never happened. i love the kardashians, but listen to me: they didn't happen. and trump? COME ON.our last few decades are blending together because the differences aren't mapping like they used to. none of this makes sense, but it all feels connected. we are a digital garden full of weeds and shit is just getting weirder. anyway, this is usually where i run out of hot water.
labels: messi, apocalypse, futurism, time_travel<|endoftext|> history, sims, sims, simulation<|endoftext|> simulation, AI, regulation, moral, ethics<|endoftext|> history, simulation, bugs, simulation<|endoftext|> politics, elon, america<|endoftext|> history, fantasy, random<|endoftext|> trump, karan, america, politics<|endoftext|>

In late July, after an apparent uptick in violent attacks, President Barack Obama called for unity and peace in a speech at the Brookings Institution. "What's going to happen is, we better find ways of sharing ideas, building bridges, keeping each other safe," Obama said. One of his final thoughts on the war in Iraq, he said, went something like this: "In the name of our shared humanity, let us not allow hate to divide us. Let us not allow divisions to tear us apart…Let us be friends; not colleagues." For Obama, peace meant the end of the war, and the end of the cycle of hate.

After taking office, Trump promised to end the war, end the torture, and bring home American prisoners. But that same day, as he was flying back to Palm Beach, Florida, his plane was hit by an apparent drone. Trump took the blame, and said, on camera, "After this, you can ask for forgiveness."

One day, however, the Trump administration actually acknowledged that drones were dangerous, and tried to end their use. Trump said, "We no longer have a strategy of just saying, 'You know what? We will go to war if we think it's necessary.'"

@julianfeijazas  I understand you're tired of being lied to by politicians.  I understand what you're going through, but  i don't think you truly understand yourself at this point.  Your priorities are not aligned with yours, you want to work more and become a billionaire at the cost of not getting rich enough, then you can retire to go off and do your dreams of being a musician, entrepreneur, or author.  You don't want to work as a service to your company and make $100k per year, right?  You want to do what you love, and to do it well.  If you become part of a system that takes away any opportunity to do this, you have lost your soul and your priorities may change.  If you're in this for the long haul, then you have to believe in yourself as well as others and that's all you can do in such an uncertain environment.  If you lose that belief and look at everything objectively, then you'll find that there's still opportunity for you in business.  When you do it, you'll win and you'll be successful.

full_text: @terronk i don’t hate it
@algierz agree low tech “tech” (literally books for example) actually have a very important role to play right now
@terronk right, this is why i’m interested in platforms / products / technologies that acknowledge the inevitability of authoritarianism, and preemptively mitigate the threat

anti-authoritarian tech stack:

signal
substack 
bitcoin 

what else?

a lot of people are wondering if/when substack will become as censorious as twitter, but substack was designed for that question not to matter. you own your mailing list, so even if you lose the platform you retain your audience. creative insurance is *part of* the product.
